S5 Fig. Functional formfor perceived costs associated with climate change.
of individuals to mitigate is in part based on their perceived costs of climate change
. We adopt a sigmoidal response curve for
) is provided in Methods). This formcaptures
the expected non-linear increase in climate change impacts (cost) as temperature increases.
Data fromthe CDIAC on carbon emissions due
to fossil-fuel burning and land-use changes, during the years 1800-2014. Land-use data is only
available from1850-2005 and so we linearly extrapolate (dashed line) to match the range of the
fossil-fuel data. The sumof the emission trajectories is used to drive the model up to the year
2014, fromwhich point the behavioural component of the socio-climate model is initiated.
S7 Fig. Emissions in the absence of behavioural change.
emissions should there be no change in human
) takes the historical emission trajectory (solid line) as human
behaviour is not modelled here. Post 2014,
) follows a saturating function (dashed line) to
capture the saturation of global population size and energy needs. Details of this functional
formcan be found in the Methods section.
S8 Fig. Comparing per capita CO
ture anomaly (solid line) above the 1850-1900 baseline value and CO
(dashed line) are shown for the 1850-2014. Data was obtained fromthe CDIAC data repository
]. It is clear that despite exceeding a 1 degree temperature anomaly, the global emissions
show no obvious signs of decreasing. The current temperature anomaly is
not yet high enough to spark a global decrease in emissions.
Total industrial CO2 emissions fromthe ten countries
with the greatest cumulative output. Data was obtained fromthe CDIAC data repository [
Note the termination of the green curve marks the dissolution of the Soviet Union and the
beginning of the yellow curve marks the formation of the Russian Federation.
fromthe ten countries with the greatest cumulative output. Data was obtained fromthe
]. From1950-1980 we observe strong increases in emissions per
capita among most of these countries as is seen globally in
in 1980 and follow slight downwards trends demonstrating a degree of country-level move-
ment towards mitigation. Globally, this is not the case, however.
Charting pathways to climate change mitigation in a coupled socio-climate model
